abstract: The government’s decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put Amazon, the nation’s largest bookseller, in a powerful position to decide how much an e-book will cost.
snippet: The government’s decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put Amazon, the nation’s largest bookseller, in a powerful position to decide how much an e-book will cost.
lead_paragraph: The government’s decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put the Internet retailer Amazon in a powerful position: the nation’s largest bookseller may now get to decide how much an e-book will cost, and the book world is quaking over the potential consequences.

headline.main: Cut in E-Book Pricing by Amazon Is Set to Shake Rivals
headline.print_headline: Amazon to Cut E-Book Prices, Shaking Rivals

abstract: Also, the new chief executive of Sony promises “difficult decisions” to revive the company, and Ann Romney starts a Twitter account to respond to comments from a Democratic strategist.
snippet: Also, the new chief executive of Sony promises “difficult decisions” to revive the company, and Ann Romney starts a Twitter account to respond to comments from a Democratic strategist.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Wednesday became an important player in the future of digital books, Julie Bosman writes, with the filing of an antitrust lawsuit against Apple and five of the largest book publishers. (Three of those publishers — Hachette Book Group, Simon & Schuster and HarperCollins — have agreed to settle; Macmillan and Penguin Group USA have not.) The impact: lower prices for e-books, as Amazon is freed to charge whatever price it wants, she writes, and, relatedly, an expected enhanced market position for Amazon.com.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Scrutiny for E-Book Pricing, and Phone-Hacking Lawsuits in U.S.
